Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Expectation2: Ensure the safe and punctual operation of the subway train.
Situation2: A minor signal delay up ahead requires careful speed adjustments to maintain the schedule without causing abrupt movements.
Story:
I was just settling into my seat in the operator’s cabin when my phone buzzed. It was Mina, an old classmate I’d run into last week. “Hey! Can you recommend a good restaurant near the station? I’m meeting someone tonight,” her message read. As an acquaintance, I felt the familiar tug of obligation—I didn’t want to seem rude or unhelpful, especially since she’d been so friendly.

But just as I started typing a reply, the control panel flashed a warning: minor signal delay ahead. I had to adjust the train’s speed, keep an eye on the signals, and make sure the ride stayed smooth for the passengers. My job demanded my full attention; any distraction could mean a safety risk or a late arrival.

I stared at my phone, thumb hovering over the screen, while my other hand gripped the controls. The pressure built inside me—Mina was waiting for a quick answer, but the train and its hundred passengers needed me, too. I could feel my heart race as I wrestled with the urge to help a friend and the responsibility to keep everyone safe.
